captions.text:
Hey everyone, this is Mark Wiens with eating
Thai food dot com.

I'm at one of my favorite Thai street food
neighborhoods in Bangkok, Thailand, Ramkhamhaeng

Soi 29 and I'm heading to a tasty restaurant
just down the road, going to grab some Isaan
style Thai food.

One of the most important things about ordering
a Thai meal is to get a well rounded combination

of flavors and tastes. So my meal has just
arrived and I'm going to show you guys exactly

what I ordered and how you can also order
it that way.

This dish is called som tam thai prik ha met,
green papaya salad with five chillies. It's

crisp, it's a little bit sweet, a little bit
sour, it has a nice chili kick to it.

Another dish I ordered is a smoked catfish
salad known as larb pla duk, this is one of

my favorite dishes actually, I eat it almost
everyday.

And then I ordered up a pork dish known as
nam tok moo. It normally comes with a lot

of fat mixed in, but I'm not big on the fat,
so I ordered it mai man, which means no fat,
it's like a grilled pork salad, it's fantastic.

Then I ordered something called yam ruam mit
talay, it's like a clear mung bean noodle
salad.

Lastly to round out this meal, I've ordered
tom saap sekong moo, a sour Isaan soup made

with pork ribs to make it extra flavorful.
Wonderful!

To accompany all of this food it's most typical
to order something known as khao neow, sticky

rice. So you grab a piece of sticky rice and
what you want to do is flavor it with the

different sauces from the dishes, so I'll
dip it in the som tam first, it flavors it
wonderfully.

If you love Thai food and you want to take
your eating to the next level, be sure to

grab a copy of the Eating Thai Food Guide,
it includes hundreds of different Thai dishes,

delicious Thai dishes, and it shows you instructions
on how to order them exactly how you want

them and even where to get them. So be sure
to click the link below, grab a copy of the

Eating Thai Food Guide and start taking advantage
of the awesome Thai food available in Bangkok
and throughout the country.

So all the remains of the feast are a few
fish bones, I'm stuffed and very happy. OK,

so that two hundred and forty baht for this
whole meal.

So anyway, grab a copy of the Eating Thai
Food Guide, I know you're going to love it,

it's full of all kinds of delicious Thai food
and you're going to learn how to order Thai
food exactly the way you want it.

That's it for me today, make sure you have
the best Thai food experience you can have!

title: Thai Street Food Menu in Bangkok (Eating Thai Food Guide) อาหารอีสาน

comments.author: BrazitodeWawa

comments.text:
Bro, looks like a renegade monk. Not sure if he's American but everyone 
knows Thai people love their food, if not obsessed with it. It's also to no 
surprize that their food is inexpensive and almost every dish is 
accompanied by rice. I like your menu tho, it's not what a typical 
westerner would order. I would buy your book but I already have a free 
guide, just here to see what others picked.
 
I've had a Thai friend leave a few years ago who never knew Thailand, even 
tho he was born there. All he tells me is food, food, and some news, then 
food again. There are a few dishes I liked that were not mentioned in the 
video but I don't know their names, one is a salad with shrimp, another was 
simply red pork with garlic and a soup like miso but with noodles, only 
veggies, a little seafood. I'm sure one day I'll try more but until then 
tacos and sammiches are my diet.﻿

comments.text:
Hi Mark, thanks for your guide in food Vlogs. I wished I had known about 
all this information from you when I went to Thailand back in 2002. I just 
haven't had the time to back since then, but now I've subscribed to your 
channel, I won't miss out on any good foods out there. I'm Laotion and I 
love all kinds of foods, but my favorite dish is "beef larb". I was wonder 
if you would be so kind to find the correct recipe to make this dish? I've 
searched everyone's videos and most of them make it wrong, in my opinion. 
Or if you happen to visit Laos to record someone make it, that would be 
great too. Thanks for all you awesome videos, and safe travels, my friend.﻿

comments.author: Gabriel Utube

comments.text:
Som Tam is the Central Thai name for Papaya salad. It is thought to have 
originated in Laos or Northeastern Thailand. In these area the dish is 
called "Tam Maak Hoong". So if you want to eat the "Thai" variant with 
peanuts and dried shrimp, you should ask for "Som Tam Thai" just to be 
sure.

comments.text:
In Thailand call som tam thai and som tam poo. - som tam thai to enter a 
dried shrimp,peanut. don't have a crab. - som tam poo to enter a crab,don't 
have dried shrimp,peanut. You can mix 2 kind of som tam, It's call ' som 
tum thai poo ' sorry for my grammar but i want to tell you .. I'M THAI.
